oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Pushmataha
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Portrait of Choctaw chief Pushmataha wearing a military uniform of the U. S. Army.

Pushmataha (circa 1764-1824) was one of the most renowned leaders of the Choctaw people. He grew up near Fort St. Stephens, a trading post located in present-day Alabama and acquired a leadership role early in his life. In the early 1800s, Pushmataha emerged as a spokesman for the Choctaws in negotiations with the U. S. government. At the outbreak of the Creek War (1813-1814), he was largely responsible for maintaining peaceful relations with the Americans while instigating attacks on the Creek Indians.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas L. (Thomas Loraine), 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
